22.25: In earlier times in Judea they used to leave the bridegroom and the bride alone one hour before their entry into the bridal chamber, so that he may become intimate with her,
22.26: but in Galilee they did not do so.
22.27: In earlier times in Judea they used to set up two groomsmen, one for him and one for her, in order to examine the bridegroom and the bride when they enter the bridal chamber, and in Galilee they did not do so.

22.31: If I say [that it refers] to the first clause?  [If so,] It should have read, “He who acted [according to this custom]!”
22.32: And [if you will say that it refers] to the last clause, it should have read, “He who was not examined.”
22.34: Indeed [it refers] to the first clause, and recite it [thus]:
22.37: But it reads, “He who did not act [in this way]!”
22.38: Rather Rava said this is what it says:
22.39: He who did not act according to the custom of Galilee in Galilee but [acted] according to the custom of Judea in Galilee cannot make a virginity claim.
22.4: In general I could say to you that she receives nothing; but it is different here, because the first one had married her.
22.41: Indeed [it refers] to the last clause, and read it this way,
22.43: It is the same whether [the woman is] an Israelite widow or a priestly widow  — her kethubah is a maneh.
22.44: The court of the priests collected for a virgin four hundred zuz, and the sages did not protest.
22.46: And the widow of a priest -her ketubah is two hundred.
22.47: But we have taught in our Mishnah:
22.48: It is the same whether [the woman is] an Israelite widow or a priestly widow  — her kethubah is a maneh.
22.5: But let us be concerned that she fornicated while betrothed to him!
22.51: At first they enacted for a virgin four hundred zuz and for a widow a maneh.
22.7: For instance he betrothed her and immediately had intercourse with her.
22.8: There are those who teach this in reference to our Mishnah:
22.9: A virgin, who was a widow, a divorcee, or a halutzah from marriage— her kethubah is a maneh, and there is no claim of non-virginity upon her.

23.0: When they saw that the treated them  lightly, they enacted for them two hundred zuz.

23.13: “No, rather [it occurred] before I betrothed you and my acquisition was a mistaken acquisition” —
23.14: Rabban Gamaliel and Rabbi Eliezer say:
23.15: she is believed. Rabbi Joshua says:
23.16: We do not live by her mouth, rather she is in the presumption of having had intercourse before she was betrothed and having deceived him, until she brings proof for her statement.

23.18: Rav Judah and Rav Huna say:
23.19: He is liable [to pay]. And R. Nahman and R. Yohanan say:

23.22: He is liable [to pay]–in the case of “certain” and “perhaps” “certain is preferable.
23.24: He is exempt [from paying]–leave the money in the possession of its present owner.
23.26: The opinion of R. Huna and Rav Judah corresponds with that of Shmuel,
23.28: She was pregnant and they said to her,
23.29: “What is the nature of this fetus?’
23.3: The court of the priests, etc.: Judah said that Shmuel said:
23.30: [And she answered, “It is] from so-and-so and he is a priest.”
23.31: Rabban Gamaliel and Rabbi Eliezer say:
23.33: And R. Judah said in the name of Shmuel:
23.35: And R. Shmuel b. Judah said to Rav Judah:
23.36: Toothy one! You said to us in the name of Shmuel [that] the halakhah follows Rabban Gamaliel even in the first Mishnah.

23.38: Even though one could say, “Leave the money in the possession of its [present] owner” [still] Rabban Gamaliel would say: “certain” is preferable.

23.43: Alternatively: Rabban Gamaliel says it only there, because we say: “Leave her in her presumptive state,” but here what presumptive state has he got?
23.44: It is also reasonable, as we have answered, that R. Nahman follows the opinion of Rabban Gamaliel,

24.0: for if it were [not] so, there would be a difficulty between one halakhah and another halakhah, for we hold [that] in civil matters the halakhah follows R. Nahman, whereas in this [case] R. Judah [said] in the name of Shmuel [that] the halakhah follows Rabban Gamaliel.
24.1: Rather, it is as we resolved, conclude [so] from this.
24.10: Two hundred zuz and a maneh. Elazar says:
24.13: Two hundred zuz and a maneh, he holds like R. Meir who says
24.14: that whether he knew or did not know [she was a mukat etz] she gets as her kethubah two hundred zuz.
24.16: A maneh or nothing, because he holds like the Rabbis who say that
24.17: whether he knew of her or did not [she was a mukat etz], she gets a maneh.
24.18: It is understandable why R. Elazar does not say as R. Yohanan says because he interprets it  according to the Rabbis.But why does R. Yohanan not say as R. Elazar?
24.19: He holds that if he married her in the presumption of her being a virgin and she is found to have had intercourse, she has a ketubah of a maneh.

24.21: It is understandable, why, according to R. Elazar we have taught two cases [in the Mishnah]
24.22: one to exclude the opinion of Rami b. Hama, and one to exclude the opinion of R. Hiyya b. Abin in the name of R. Sheshet.
24.23: But according to R. Yohanan why are two cases necessary?
24.24: One to show you the strength of Rabban Gamaliel, and one to show you the strength of R. Joshua.
24.25: The first case to show you the strength of R. Joshua, that, although one could say there migo, she is not believed. The second case to show you the strength of Rabban Gamaliel, that, although one cannot say there migo, she is believed.
24.26: They saw her talking with someone in the marketplace, and they said to her,
24.27: “What sort of a man is he?”
24.28: And she answered, “He is so-and-so and he is a priest” —
24.29: Rabban Gamaliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: she is believed,
24.3: “I was struck by a piece of wood”,  And he says,
24.30: And Rabbi Joshua says: we do not live by her mouth, rather she is in the presumption of having had relations with a natin or a mamzer, until she brings proof for her statement.
24.31: She was pregnant and they said to her,
24.32: “What is the nature of this fetus?’
24.33: And she answered, “It is from so-and-so and he is a priest.” —
24.34: Rabban Gamaliel and Rabbi Eliezer say:
24.35: she is believed, And Rabbi Joshua says:
24.36: we do not live by her mouth, rather she is in the presumption of having had relations with a natin or a mamzer, until she brings proof for her statement.
24.37: GEMARA. What is the meaning of “talking”?
24.39: She was secluded. R. Assi said:
24.4: “No, you, rather you have been trampled by a man:”
24.41: It is understandable according to Ze’iri, for that is why it says, “talking.” But according to R.Assi why does it say “talking”?
24.42: It is a euphemism, as it is written: “She eats, and wipes her mouth, and says, ‘I have done no wickedness’” (Proverbs 30:20).
24.43: It is understandable according to Ze’iri that it teaches in the Mishnah two cases: “talking” and “pregnant,”
24.44: but according to R. Assi, why does the Mishnah teach two cases?
24.45: One case to declare her fit and one case to declare her daughter fit.
24.46: This goes well according to him who says that
24.47: he who declares her fit declares also her daughter fit. But according to him who says that
24.48: he who declares her fit declares her daughter unfit, what is there to say?
24.49: Assi holds like the one who says that he who declares her fit declares also her daughter fit.
24.5: Rabban Gamaliel and Rabbi Eliezer say:
24.51: According to Ze’iri who said: What is “talking”? She was secluded, and R. Joshua said that she is not believed, did not Rav say:
24.52: We punish with lashes for seclusion but we do not prohibit on account of seclusion? Should we say that this does not follow R. Joshua?
24.53: You may even say that it follows R. Joshua, for they set a higher standard in matters of priestly lineage.
24.55: If they saw her go in with someone into a hidden place
24.6: she is believed, And Rabbi Joshua says:
24.7: We do not live by her mouth, rather she is in the presumption of having been trampled by a man, until she brings proof for her statement.

25.0: or into a ruin, and they said to her,
25.1: “What sort of a man is he?”
25.10: But it teaches: Into a hidden place or into a ruin!
25.11: Rather say one refers to the ruin of a town and one refers to the ruin of a field.
25.12: And they are both necessary. For if it had taught us only concerning a ruin of a town, I might have said that in this case Rabban Gamaliel declares her fit because most of the men of the town are fit with regard to her,
25.13: but in the case of  a ruin of a field, where most of the men are unfit with regard to her, I might say that he agrees with R. Joshua.
25.14: And if it  had told us only this case, I might have said that only in this case did R. Joshua say that she is not believed, but in that case I might say that he agrees with Rabban Gamaliel; therefore it was necessary to state both cases.
25.16: This is testimony which a woman is fit to give. But R. Joshua says:
25.19: Do you not agree that in the case of a woman who was captured, and there are witnesses that she was captured, and she says, “I am pure,” that she is not believed?
25.2: and she answered, “He is a priest and he is the son of the brother of my father”:
25.22: what a difference there is between this case and that case.
25.23: In that case there are witnesses, and in this case there are no witnesses.
25.25: In this case too there are witnesses, for her stomach reaches up to her teeth.
25.27: Most non-Jews are unrestrained in sexual matters.
25.29: There is no guardian in sexual matters.
25.3: Rabban Gamaliel and R. Eliezer say:
25.30: This applies only in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to herself but in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to her daughter all agree that the child is a shetuki.
25.31: What did he say to them and what did they answer him?
25.33: You have answered us with regard to the pregnant woman, what will you answer us with regard to the woman whom they saw talking to a man?
25.35: The woman whom they saw talking to a man is the same as the captive woman.
25.37: The captive woman is different, for most of the idolators are unrestrained in sexual matters.
25.39: Here also, since she hid herself, there is no guardian in sexual matters.
25.40: Now in any case it teaches two cases: he woman whom they saw talking to a man and the pregnant woman! This is a refutation of R. Assi,
25.42: But let him note this difference–there most of the men are unfit with regard to her, but here most of the men are fit with regard to her!
25.43: This supports R. Joshua b. Levi, for R. Joshua b. Levi said:
25.44: He who declares her fit declares her fit even when most of the men are unfit, and he who declares her unfit declares her unfit even when most of the men are fit.
25.46: He who declares her fit declares also her daughter fit, and he who declares her unfit declares also her daughter unfit.
25.48: He who declares her fit declares her daughter unfit.
25.50: What is the reason of R. Elazar?
25.51: It is understandable with regard to her, she has the presumption of fitness, but her daughter has no presumption of fitness.
25.52: Elazar raised an objection to R. Yohanan:
25.53: This only applies to the testimony of the woman with regard to herself, but in the case of the testimony of the woman with regard to her daughter, all agree that the child is a shetuki.
25.54: Does this not mean a shetuki and unfit?
25.56: But is there such a thing as a shetuki who is fit?
25.57: Yes, according to Shmuel, for Shmuel said
25.58: If ten priests are standing together and one of them goes away and has intercourse with a woman, the child is a shetuki.
25.59: Now what does shetuki mean here?
25.6: We do not live by her mouth, rather she is in the presumption of having had intercourse with a natin or a mamzer, until she brings proof for her words.
25.60: Is it to say that he is “silenced” from the property of his father? This is obvious! Do we even know who his father is?
25.61: Rather it means that he is silenced from the rights of being a priest, for it is written: “And it shall be for him and for his seed after him the covenant of an everlasting priesthood” (Numbers 2513): ne whose seed legitimately descends from him, excluding this one, whose seed does not descend from him.
25.62: A betrothed couple once came before R. Joseph. She said,
25.63: “It is from him.”  And he said:
25.7: It goes well according to Ze’iri, that it teaches two cases: into a hidden place or into a ruin.
25.8: But according to R. Assi who said: “she had intercourse,” why does it teach two cases?
25.9: It teaches only one case: Into the hidden place of a ruin.

26.10: The halakhah is according to Rabban Gamaliel, but you should not act on it, unless most men are fit for her,
26.11: whereas here most men are unfit for her!
26.12: And according to your reasoning is not this statement in itself difficult? First he says
26.13: ‘The halackah is…” and then “do not act on it”!
26.15: The one ruling applies ab initio, the other ex post facto, and in this case it is ex post facto.
26.17: Did R. Joshua say: She is not believed?
26.19: R. Joshua and R. Judah b. Batera testified concerning the widow [of one who was] of a mixed family that she is fit to marry a priest.
26.2: What should we be concerned about?
26.22: There the woman marries, and she examines [his lineage] and [then] marries; but here the woman who is licentious; does she first examine and then act licentiously?
26.24: One statement of R. Joshua and the other statement of R. Joshua contradict each other, but one statement of Rabban Gamaliel does not contradict the other statement?
26.25: But does not the concluding clause teach: Rabban Gamaliel said to them:
26.26: We accept your testimony, but what can we do, since Rabban Yohanan b. Zakkai decreed that no court be set up for this purpose because the priests will obey you to distance but not to bring near?
26.28: There is no contradiction between the statement of Rabban Gamaliel and the other statement of Rabban Gamaliel,
26.29: because there it is “certain” and here it is “perhaps.”
26.30: Neither is there a contradiction between the one statement of R. Joshua and the other statement of R. Joshua,
26.31: because in that case there is one doubt and here there is a double doubt.
26.32: Therefore, according to Rabban Gamaliel the “the certain” is so strong that even where there is only one doubt he declares her fit,
26.33: and the “perhaps” is so weak that even where there is a double doubt he declares her unfit.
26.34: And according to R. Joshua one doubt   is so strong that even in the case where she stakes a “certain” claim he declares her unfit, and a double doubt is so light that even in the case where she stakes a “perhaps” claim he declares her fit.
26.36: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? Anyone about whom there is no doubt on account of mamzerut, natinut or on account of slaves of the kings.
26.4: Rav Judah said that Shmuel said:
26.5: The halakhah is according to Rabban Gamaliel.
26.7: And in this case, if he did not admit [that it was his], would Rabban Gamaliel declare fit?
26.8: Did not Shmuel say to Rav Judah:

27.0: I have heard that when there is none of these defects in the family, they may marry her into the priesthood.
27.1: Shimon b. Elazar said in the name of R. Meir and R. Shimon the son of Menasia also said it:
27.10: And further: R. Shimon b. Elazar said in the name of R. Meir and R. Shimon b. Menasia also said like him:
27.11: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? When a halal was mixed up in [his lineage], for the Israelites know the mamzerim who are among them, but they do not know the halalim who are among them. But it says in the first clause [that if there is a doubt regarding] a halal [in the family], she is fit to marry into the priesthood!
27.13: There is a difference between them concerning a person who when he is called a mamzer protests and when he is called a halal is silent.
27.14: The first Tanna holds that every person who when called “unfit” is silent is considered unfit, and thus the first Tanna said:
27.15: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? When with regard to her there is no one who is silent if he is called mamzer or natin, or slave of the king, or halal.
27.17: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? Anyone about whom there is no doubt on account of mamzerut, natinut or on account of slaves of the kings.
27.19: I have heard that when there is none of these defects in the family, they may marry her into the priesthood.
27.2: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? When a doubtful halal was mixed up in it,
27.20: Shimon b. Elazar said in the name of R. Meir and R. Shimon the son of Menasia also said it:
27.21: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? When a doubtful halal was mixed up in it, for the Israelites know the mamzerim who are among them, but they do not know the halalim who are among them.
27.22: The Master said: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? Anyone about whom there is no doubt on account of mamzerut, natinut or on account of slaves of the kings.
27.23: And R. Shimon b. Elazar said to the first Tanna of R. Meir:
27.24: If you have heard that R. Meir declares the person fit in the case of silence, this is not when he is called halal and is silent, but when he is called mamzer and is silent. And why is he silent? Because he says to himself. a mamzer is well-known.
27.25: But if he is called mamzer and he protests or he is called halal and is silent he is unfit, for the reason he is silent is because he thinks,
27.26: it is enough if he is not excluded from the congregation.
27.28: R. Yose says:If he is called mamzer and is silent, he is fit, and if he is called halal and is silent, he is unfit.
27.3: for the Israelites know the mamzerim who are among them, but they do not know the halalim who are among them.
27.30: If he is called halal and is silent he is fit, but if he is called mamzer and is silent, he is unfit.
27.32: it happened that a young girl went down to draw water from a spring and she was raped.
27.34: if most of the inhabitants of the town marry [their daughters] into the priesthood, this [girl] may [also] marry into the priesthood.
27.35: GEMARA. Rava said to R. Nahman:
27.36: According to whom did R. Yohanan b. Nuri say [his statement in the Mishnah]?
27.37: If according to Rabban Gamaliel, he declares her fit even when there is a majority of unfit!  And if it is according to R. Joshua, he declares her unfit even when there is a majority of fit!
27.39: Rav Judah said that Rav said:
27.5: Which is the widow of one of a mixed family? Anyone about whom there is no doubt on account of mamzerut, natinut or on account of slaves of the kings.
27.6: [By implication] if there is a doubt on account of a halal in the family she is fit.
27.7: Why should these be different? Because these are Biblical? A halal is also Biblical.
27.9: I have heard that when there is none of these defects in the family they may marry her into the priesthood. This is the same as that which the first Tanna taught!

28.0: The incident happened in the marketplaces of Tzippori, and this follows R. Ammi,
28.10: We go after the majority of the town and we do not go after the majority of the passing company.
28.12: These move about and these are stationary!
28.14: we go after the majority of the inhabitants of the town, but only when there is also the majority of the passing company with it,
28.15: but only when there is also the majority of the passing company with it, of the town alone, nor after the majority of the passing company alone.
28.16: What is the reason? It is a decree not to go after the majority of the passing company in order to prevent going after the majority of the inhabitants of the town.
28.17: But even in the case of the majority of the inhabitants of the town, if he, went to her, he who separates himself separates himself from the majority?
28.18: It is only necessary when she went to him so that he was stationary, and R. Zera said:
28.19: All that is stationary is considered as half to half.
28.2: And that is when a company of fit men passed by there, and it also follows R. Yannai
28.20: But do we require two majorities?
28.22: Nine [butcher] shops, all of them  sell ritually slaughtered meat and one sells meat not ritually slaughtered and he bought from one of them and he does not know from which one he bought it is prohibited because of the doubt.
28.23: But if [meat] was found, follow the majority?
28.24: And if you will say that this refers to a case when the gates of the city are not closed, so that a majority came also from outside, did not R. Zera say:
28.25: Even when the gates of the city are closed?
28.26: They added an extra degree of stringency in matters of lineage.
28.27: The text says: R. Zera said:
28.28: All that is stationary is considered as half to half. Whether this results in a leniency or in a stringency.
28.29: From where does R. Zera derive this?
28.30: If I say from [the following baraita]: nine butcher shops, all of them sell ritually slaughtered meat and one sells meat not ritually slaughtered and he bought in one of them and he does not know in which of them he bought, it is prohibited because of the doubt; But if [meat] was found, one goes after the majority? There it leads to a stringency!
28.31: Rather [he derives it] from [the following]: If there were nine frogs and one sheretz and he touches one of them and he does not know which of them he touched he is unclean because of the doubt?
28.32: There it also leads to a stringency.
28.33: But [rather] from [the following]: If there were nine sheratzim and one frog and he touches one of them and he does not know which of them he touched: In the private domain he is unclean because of the doubt; in a public domain, he is clean because of the doubt.
28.34: And how do we know this from the Torah?
28.35: The verse says: “And if he lie in wait for him and rise up against him.” [He is not guilty of murder] until he intended [to kill] him.
28.37: they said in the school of R. Yannai:
28.38: This excludes one who throws a stone into [a group of people].
28.4: If she had intercourse in the marketplaces she is fit for the priesthood.
28.40: What was the exact case? If you say there were nine non-Jews and one Israelite? Let it be sufficient for him that the majority are non-Jews.
28.41: Alternatively, if it was half and half, [the rule is that] when there is a doubt in capital cases one takes a lenient view!
28.42: Rather it is necessary when there were nine Israelites and one non-Jew, so that the non-Jew is stationary, and whatever is stationary is considered as half and half.
28.43: It was stated: R. Hiyya b. Ashi said in the name of Rav:
28.44: The halakhah follows R. Yose. And R. Hanan b. Rava said in the name of Rav:
28.47: And for matters of lineage we do not require two majorities?
28.5: In the marketplaces, does that make sense?
28.7: If she had intercourse at the time of [the wagons arriving at] the marketplaces she is fit for the priesthood.
28.8: But if someone went out from Tzippori and had intercourse with her, the offspring is a shetuki.
28.9: Like the following: When R. Dimi came he said in the name of Ze’iri who said in the name of R. Hanina, and some say: Ze’iri said in the name of R. Hanina:

29.0: If one found in it an abandoned child — if the majority were non-Jews [the child is] a non-Jew, if the majority are Jews [the child is] a Jew, half and half, [the child is] a Jew.

29.11: [They have taught this only] with regard to removing stones from on top of it.
29.12: But did Shmuel really say this?
29.13: Did not R. Joseph say that R. Judah said in the name of Shmuel:
29.14: We do not follow the majority when it comes to saving a life?
29.15: Rather when Shmuel said it, it referred to the first clause:
29.16: If the majority [of the inhabitants of the town are] non-Jews [the child is] a non-Jew. [On this] Shmuel said:
29.17: And with regard to removing stones from on top of it.
29.18: If the majority [of the inhabitants of the town consist of] non-Jews [the child is] a non-Jew: For what practical purpose [was this taught]?

29.20: To feed him meat not ritually slaughtered.
29.21: If the majority [of the inhabitants of the town are] Jews [the child is] a Jew: For what practical purpose [is this taught]?
29.23: That one returns to him a lost object.
29.24: If [the inhabitants of the town are] half and half [the child is] Jewish: For what practical purpose [is this taught]?
29.28: If it was an ox of ours that gored an ox of his?
29.29: [In this case] let him say to him: “Bring evidence that you are an Israelite — and take!”
29.3: [They have taught this only] with regard to removing stones from on top of it.
29.30: Rather it is necessary when an ox of his gored an ox of ours:
29.31: One half he pays, and with regard to the other half he says to them:
29.32: “Bring evidence that I am not an Israelite and I will pay you.”
29.33: May we return to you “A virgin is wedded.”
29.34: A woman became a widow or was divorced. She says,

59.23: If he can give it back, let him give it back. And if he cannot give it back, why is he guilty?

59.26: When his friend put liquids of terumah into his mouth.
59.28: When a non-priest ate his own terumah

59.4: He who would have been sentenced to strangulation, is either drowned in the river or dies from suffocation.

59.8: The reason [for the view] of R. Nehunia b. Hakaneh, is from here:
59.9: “And if the people of the land should shut their eyes from that man, when he gives of his offspring to Molech, [and not put him to death]; then I will set my face against that man, and against his family, and will cut him off” (Leviticus 20:5). The Torah says:

6.0: and he has the mandated act of intercourse and then separates from her. And [then] he observes the seven days of the [wedding] feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.

6.10: And in a village, although water had not been put on the meat, it is not sold.
6.11: But where [then] will you find [the rule] of R. Hisda?
6.13: For instance, [in] Mata Mehasia, which is neither a city nor a village.
6.14: It has been taught according to R. Hisda:
6.15: If his bread was baked and his meat prepared and his wine mixed and water had been put on the meat and the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride died, they bring the dead [person] into a room and the bridegroom and the bride into the bridal chamber, and he has the mandated act of intercourse and [then] separates [himself from her]. And [then] he keeps the seven days of the [wedding-] feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.

6.2: And they do not withhold jewellery from the bride all the thirty days.
6.21: He sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
6.24: Although they said [that] there is no mourning on a festival, he keeps [mourning] in private.
6.25: Joseph the son of Rava expounded in the name of Rava:
6.26: They taught this only if he had not yet had intercourse with her but if he had [already] intercourse, his wife may sleep with him.
6.27: But here we are dealing with a case where he had intercourse, and it still it teaches [that]
6.28: he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women?
6.29: When did he say [this]? With regard to his wife becoming a menstruant.
6.3: [But this is] only [if] the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride [died], because there is [then] no one who should prepare for them [for the wedding], but not [in case of] the reverse.
6.4: Rafram b. Papa said [that] R. Hisda said:
6.5: They taught [this] only when water had [already] been put on the meat,
6.6: but if water had not [yet] been put on the meat, it is to be sold.

60.0: and [at the same time] tore the silk garments of his neighbor.
60.10: What is the [practical] difference between the one answer and the other answer?
60.11: The difference between them is [in the following case]: One who carries a knife in the public domain and it tore silk garments in its passage:
60.12: According to the answer that the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting”
60.13: here also the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting.”  And according to the answer that he cannot take it back, here he can take it back.
60.14: The text [stated above]: R. Abin said:
60.15: If someone threw [on Sabbath] an arrow from the beginning of four [cubits] to the end of four [cubits] and it tore silk garments in its passage he is exempt [from payment], for the “uprooting” was necessary for the “putting down.”
60.16: Bibi b. Abaye raised an objection:
60.17: If someone stole a purse on Shabbat he is obligated [to pay], because he was guilty of stealing before he came to the [transgression of] the prohibition punishable with stoning,
60.18: but if he dragged it along he is exempt [from payment], because the desecration of Shabbat and the stealing come at the same time.
60.2: R. Nehunia b. Hakaneh agrees that, if someone stole [forbidden] fat belonging to his neighbor and ate it, he is liable [to pay], because he was guilty of stealing before he came to the prohibition with of [forbidden] fat.
60.20: Here also we should say: The lifting up is necessary for the carrying out!
60.21: Here also we should say: The lifting up is necessary for the carrying out!
60.22: [But] is he, in such a case guilty [of trangressing Shabbat]?
60.23: Did not R. Simon say [that] R. Ammi said in the name of R. Yohanan:
60.24: If someone was removing objects from one corner to another corner and changed his mind and carried them out he is exempt because the taking up was not from the outset for that [purpose]?
60.25: Do not say [he picked it up] in order to hide it, rather say [he picked it up] in order to carry it out. Here we are dealing with a case where he [paused and] remained standing [for a while].
60.26: For what purpose did he stand?
60.27: If to adjust [the weight], this is the usual way.
60.28: Rather where he stood still in order to rest. But if he stood in order to adjust the weight what is the rule?
60.3: Shall we say he disagrees with R. Abin? For R. Abin said:
60.4: If someone threw an arrow [on Shabbat] from the beginning of four [cubits] to the end of four [cubits] and it tore silk garments in its passage he is exempt [from payment], for the uprooting was necessary for the putting down.
60.5: Here too the lifting up was necessary for the eating.
60.7: There the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting”; but here the eating is possible without the “lifting up,” for if he wants, he could bend down and eat.
60.9: there if he wants to take it back, he cannot take it back; but here, he can put it back.

61.0: He would be exempt. [If so] instead of teaching “but if he dragged it along he is exempt [from payment],” let it teach the distinction in the same case:
61.1: “When was this said?  If he stood still to rest; but if [he stood still] to adjust the weight, he is exempt [from payment]”?
61.10: Rather it was medium sized. But where did he carry it to?
61.11: If he carried it into the public domain, there is a transgression of Shabbat but no stealing, and if he carried it into the private domain, there is stealing but no transgression of Shabbat!
61.12: No, it is necessary [to state it] when he carried it out to the sides of the public road.
61.14: If according to R. Eliezer, who says:
61.15: The sides of the public road are like the public road, there is a transgression of Shabbat but no stealing and
61.16: if it is according to the rabbis, who say: The sides of the public road are not like the public road, there is stealing but no transgression of Shabbat?
61.17: Indeed, it is according to R. Eliezer, and when R. Eliezer says: The sides of the public road are like the public road, these words refer only to the obligation for transgressing Shabbat, because sometimes people push and go there, but with regard to acquiring, one does acquire there. Why [not]? Because the public is not often there.
61.19: It refers to a case where he lowered his hand to less than three [handbreadths] and received it. [And this is] according to Rava,
61.2: Rather, whose opinion is this? It is Ben Azzai who said that
61.21: The hand of a person is regarded as [a place of] four by four [handbreadths].
61.24: Indeed, when he carried it out into the public road, for he acquires also in the public ground.
61.25: [And] they differ with regard to a deduction from this Mishnah, for we have learned:
61.26: If he was pulling it out and it died in the domain of the owner, he is exempt. But if he lifted it up or brought it out from the domain of the owner and it died, he is obligated [to pay].
61.27: Ravina makes a deduction from the first clause, and R. Aha makes a deduction from the second clause.
61.28: Ravina makes a deduction from the first clause:
61.29: “If he was pulling it out and it died in the domain of the owner, he is exempt.”
61.3: one who walks is like one who stands.
61.30: The reason [he is exempt] is because it died in the domain of the owner, but if he had brought it out from the domain of the owner and it died, he would have been obligated [to pay].
61.31: Aha makes a deduction from the second clause:
61.32: “But if he lifted it up or brought it out [etc.]” Bringing out is like lifting up; just as lifting up is [an act through which the object] comes into his possession,
61.33: so too bringing out [must he an act through which the object] comes into his possession.
61.34: According to R. Aha the first clause is difficult and according to Rabina the second clause is difficult?
61.35: The first clause is not difficult to R. Aha,
61.36: for as long as it has not come into his possession it is called “in the domain of the owner.”
61.37: The second clause is not difficult to Ravina,
61.38: for we do not say [that] bringing out is like lifting up.
61.39: One who has sex with his sister, or with the sister of his father, etc.
61.4: [But] what would be the rule if he threw [the purse]?  He would be exempt [from payment]. Let him then make the distinction in the same case:
61.40: They raised a contradiction against this:
61.41: The following persons receive [the punishment of] lashes:
61.42: He who has intercourse with his sister, with the sister of his father, with the sister of his mother, with the sister of his wife, with the sister of his brother, with the wife of the brother of his father, or with a woman during menstruation,
61.5: When was this said? When he walked, but when he threw it, he is exempt.
61.6: The case of dragging it along need [to be stated]. Lest you would have said that
61.7: this is not the way of carrying out, so he teaches us [that it is a way of carrying out].
61.9: If large, this is the ordinary way [of carrying it out], and if small, this is not the ordinary way?

62.0: and we hold that one does not receive lashes and pay!
62.10: Wherever there is a monetary payment and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.11: From where does Ulla derive this?
62.12: He derives it from [the law with regard to] one person who injures another person.
62.13: Just as when one person injures another person, where there is a monetary payment and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes,
62.14: so too whenever there is a payment of money and a punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. But it is different with [the case of] one who injures another because he is liable for five things?And [if you will say] that [the payment of] money is still lighter, [one can say against this] that [here it has been excepted] from its rule [and] permitted to the court!
62.15: Rather he derives it from the case of plotting witnesses.
62.16: Just as in the case of plotting witnesses, whose transgression involves the payment of money and the punishment with lashes, they pay the money but do not receive the lashes, so too whenever there is payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.17: [But it may be argued] it is different with the case of plotting witnesses, because they do not require a warning? [And if you will say] that [the payment of] money is lighter, [one can say against this,] that they have not done any deed!
62.18: Rather he derives it from both (plotting witnesses and personal injury).
62.19: The point common to both is that there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, and in either case he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. So whenever there is payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.20: But [it may be argued] the point common to both is [also] that they both have a strict side? And if [you will say that the payment of] money is lighter, [one can say against this] that they have both a lighter side?
62.3: Here [it speaks] of his sister [who is] a young girl, and there [it speaks] of his sister [who is] a mature girl.
62.4: [But in the case of] his sister [who is] a mature girl, too, [there are damages to be paid for the] shame and damage?
62.5: It refers to one not of sound senses.
62.6: But [there are still damages to be paid for] the pain?
62.7: [It speaks of] a girl who was seduced.
62.8: Now that you have come to this, you can even say [that it speaks of] his sister [who was] a young girl [and namely when she was] an orphan and [she was] seduced.

63.0: Rather, Ulla derives it from the two words “tahat:”  It is written here “Since (tahat) he has laid with her” (Deuteronomy 22:29) and it is written there: “Eye for (tahat) eye.” Just as there he pays money and does not receive lashes, so wherever there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes.
63.10: And if you will say that
63.11: this is only when they did not warn him, but when they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay — did not R. Ammi say in the name of R. Yohanan that,
63.12: if one person struck another person a blow, for which no perutah can be claimed as damages, he receives the lashes?
63.14: If they did not warn him, why would he receive the lashes?
63.16: they warned him, and the reason [why he receives the lashes and does not pay] is because the damages do not amount to a perutah, but if they amount to a perutah he pays the money but does not receive the lashes!
63.18: The Torah has expressly stated that plotting witnesses have to pay money; so [here] also the Torah has expressly stated that the person who injures another person has to pay money.
63.19: Where was the teaching of R. Ila said? On the following:
63.2: You can even say that it speaks of his sister who was a young girl [and you can resolve the contradiction in the following way]:
63.20: “We testify that So-and-so owes his fellow two hundred zuz” and they were found to be plotting witnesses, they receive the lashes and pay, for the verse that imposes upon them the lashes does not impose upon them the payment, the words of R. Meir; and the Sages say:
63.21: All who pay do not receive lashes.
63.23: He who receives lashes does not pay?
63.25: The Torah has expressly stated that plotting witnesses have to pay money.
63.26: Where has the Torah stated this?
63.27: Since; it is written: “Then you shall do to him as he had thought to do to his fellow”
63.28: (Deuteronomy 19:19); why [is it written further,] “hand for hand” (19:21)? Something that is given from hand to hand. And what is this? Money.
63.29: [And] the same applies to the case of one who injures another. Since it is written: “As he has done, so shall it be done to him” (Leviticus 24:19); Why [is it also stated] “So shall it be given to him” (Leviticus 24:20)?  A thing that can be given from hand to hand, and that is money.
63.3: Here it speaks of a case where they warned him, and here it speaks of a case where they did not warn him.
63.30: Why does R. Yohanan not say as Ulla?
63.31: If so you would abolish [the lashes accorded to one who transgresses]: “The nakedness of your sister you shall not uncover” (Leviticus 18:9).
63.5: wherever there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes and they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay the money.
63.6: From where does R. Yohanan derive this?
63.8: “According to his guilt” (Deuteronomy 25:2); you punish him because of one guilt but not because of two guilts, and immediately following [it says]: “He shall strike him with forty lashes.”
63.9: But behold when one person injures another person, in which case there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes?

64.0: [The same could be said] about one who injures another: If so you would abolish [the lashes accorded to one who transgresses], “He shall not exceed, lest, if he should exceed” (Deuteronomy 25:3).
64.1: [And the same could be said of] plotting witnesses: If so you would abolish [the the lashes accorded to one who transgresses]: “Then it shall be, if the guilty man deserve to be beaten” (Deuteronomy 25:2).
64.11: “Then the man that lay with her must give to the father of the girl fifty shekel of silver” (Deuteronomy 22:29); for the enjoyment of lying [with her he pays] fifty [shekel of silver], [and from here we infer], by implication, that there is also payment for shame and damages.
64.13: Plotting witnesses pay money and do not receive lashes, because they cannot be warned.
64.15: Know it [from the following logic]: When could we warn them?
64.16: Could we warn them at first? They will say: We have forgotten.
64.17: Could we warn them during the deed? They would [then] leave and not testify.
64.18: Could we warn them at the end? What has been has been.
64.19: Abaye raised a difficulty on this:
64.2: Rather [lashing for] plotting witnesses could be fulfilled when [the witnesses testified falsely about someone that he was] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah.
64.20: Let us warn them immediately after they have given their evidence?
64.21: Aha the son of R. Ika raised a difficulty:
64.22: Let us warn them at first and hint to them [afterwards].
64.23: Abaye changed his mind and said:
64.25: For if you thought that plotting witnesses require a warning, if we have not warned them, we would not kill them. [But then] is it possible that who they wished to kill without a warning, that they should require a warning?
64.26: Surely, we need to fulfill “then you shall do to him as he has plotted to do to his brother,” and this could not be fulfilled.
64.27: Samma the son of R. Jeremiah raised a difficulty:
64.28: But now [according to your logic], [if the witnesses testified falsely about someone that he was] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah since this case is not included in “as he had thought etc.” he should require a warning should be required!
64.3: [Similarly in the case of] one who injured another, it could be fulfilled when he struck him a blow for which no perutah can be claimed as damages.
64.30: “You shall have one manner of law” (Leviticus 24:22) [this means] a law that is equal for all of you.
64.31: Shisha, the son of R. Idi, said:
64.32: That a person who injures another person pays money and does not receive the lashes is derived from the following:
64.33: [It is written:] “And if men fight and harm a woman with child, so that she miscarries,” (Exodus 21:22): [Upon this] R. Elazar said:
64.34: The verse speaks of fighting with intent to kill, for it is written, “But if any harm follow, then you shall take a life for a life.”
64.36: If they did not warn him, why should he be killed? Hence it is obvious that he was warned, [and it is held], when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also is warned for a light matter, and [yet] the Torah says: “And if no harm follow, he shall be surely fined.”
64.38: From where [do we know] that when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also stands warned for a light matter? Perhaps it is not so!
64.39: And even if we say that it is so, how [do we know] that death is more severe?
64.4: [But you could] also say [with regard to] his sister— it could be fulfilled in the case of his sister who was a mature girl!
64.6: [The verse] “Since (tahat) he had relations with her” is required for the teaching of Abaye, for Abaye said:
64.7: The verse says, “Since he had relations with her.” This [he shall pay] for he has had relations with her, [from which we infer] by implication, that there is also payment for shame and damages.
64.8: And Ulla? He derives it from a teaching of Rava,

65.10: Rather it teaches that they imprison him; if he dies, they kill him; and if he does not die, “he shall pay for the loss of his time, and heal him.”
65.12: If they did not warn him, why should he be killed?
65.13: Rather it is clear that they warned him, and [it is held], one who was warned for a severe matter stands warned for the lighter matter and the Torah says [that if he does not die] “he shall pay for the loss of his time, and heal him.”
65.15: From where [do we know] that when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also stands warned for a light matter?
65.16: Perhaps it is not so! And even if we say that it is so, how [do we know] that death is more severe?
65.17: Perhaps lashes are more severe, for Rav said: ?
65.18: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the [golden] image?
65.19: Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi; and some say [that] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi [said] to R. Ashi:
65.2: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the [golden] image?
65.20: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit and a beating that has no limit!
65.22: From where [do you know] that he struck him intentionally, and he is cleansed from execution. Perhaps he struck him unintentionally, and he is cleansed from exile.
65.25: Whose opinion is this? R. Meir, who says: .
65.26: He receives the lashes and pays [the money]
65.27: If it is according to R. Meir, [then one who violated] his daughter should also [pay the fine]?
65.28: And if you will say that R. Meir holds [that] one may receive the lashes and pay [the money], but he does not hold [that] one may receive the death penalty and pay [the money], is this so?
65.3: Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi; and some say [that] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi [said] to R. Ashi:
65.30: If he has stolen and slaughtered [an animal] on Shabbat, or has stolen and slaughtered [an animal] for idolatry, or has stolen an ox that is to be stoned and slaughtered it, he shall pay fourfold or fivefold, the words of R. Meir, but the sages exempt him [from payment].
65.31: Has it not been stated regarding this: R. Jacob said in the name of R. Yohanan, and some say [that] R. Jeremiah said in the name of R. Shimon b. Lakish:
65.32: R. Abin and R. Elai and the whole company [of scholars] said in the name of R. Yohanan:
65.33: It refers to a case where he [who stole the animal] let it be slaughtered by another person.
65.34: But is it possible that one sins and another one is punished?
65.36: The Torah says: “And he slaughters it or sells it” (Exodus 21:37); just as the sale is performed by another person, so too the slaughter is performed by another person.
65.37: The School of R. Ishmael taught:
65.38: [The word] “or” comes to include the agent.
65.4: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit and a beating that has no limit!
65.40: [The word] “instead” comes to include the agent
65.41: Mar Zutra raises a difficulty on this:
65.42: Is it anywhere to be found that if he does [the deed] himself he is not liable and if an agent does it he is liable?
65.43: He himself [does not pay], not because he is not liable, but because he receives the more severe penalty
65.44: But if it had been slaughtered by another person, what is the reason of the rabbis who declare him free [from paying]?
65.5: Jacob from Nehar Pekod raised a difficulty:
65.6: hat works for the Rabbis who hold that life actually means [life]. But according to Rabbi, who holds that it means money, what is there to say?
65.7: Rather R. Jacob from Nehar Pekod said in the name of Rava:
65.8: [It is to derived] from the following verse: [It is written,] “Should he get up and walk about on his staff then he that smote him shall be cleansed” (Exodus 21:19).
65.9: Would you think that this one walks about in the market and that one should be killed?

66.0: Who are the Sages? R. Shimon, who says: An unfit slaughtering is not called slaughtering.
66.1: This is correct with regard to [slaughtering for] idolatry and [slaughtering of] the ox that is to be stoned, but slaughtering on Shabbat is a valid slaughtering, for we have learned:
66.10: What is R. Yohanan the Sandler’s reasoning?
66.11: As R. Hiyya expounded at the entrance of the house of the Patriarch:
66.12: “You shall keep the Shabbat for it is holy to you” (Exodus 31:14).
66.13: Just as what is holy is forbidden to be eaten, so too what has been prepared on Shabbat is forbidden to be eaten.
66.14: If [so, you might say that] just as what is holy is forbidden to be enjoyed, so too what has been prepared on Shabbat should be forbidden to be enjoyed?
66.15: It says, “to you,” from this we learn: It shall belong to you.
66.16: You might think [that it is forbidden to eat] even [what has been prepared on Shabbat] by mistake,
66.17: [therefore] it is said: “Those who desecrate it shall surely die” (Exodus 31:14).  I have told you this only when it was done intentionally, not when it was done by mistake.
66.18: Aha and Rabina argue about this.
66.2: One who slaughters [an animal] on Shabbat or on Yom Kippur, although he is liable for the death penalty his slaughtering is valid?
66.20: What has been prepared on Shabbat [is forbidden] by the Torah, and one says: by the rabbis.
66.22: The one who says: By the Torah, as we have said [above].
66.23: [And] the one who says: By the rabbis — the verse says: .
66.24: “It is holy,” “it” is holy, but what has been prepared on it is not holy
66.25: According to the one who says [that the prohibition is only] by the rabbis, what is the reason of the rabbis who declare him exempt?
66.26: The rabbis declare him exempt only with regard to other cases.
66.27: But [with regard to] one who slaughtered for idolatry [one can ask:] as soon as he has cut a little it has become forbidden, so when he continues the slaughtering he is not slaughtering what belongs to the owner?
66.29: [It refers to a case] when he says [that] he worships it with the completion of the slaughtering.
66.3: He holds the opinion of R. Yohanan the Sandler, for it has been taught:
66.30: [But with regard to] the ox that is to he stoned, it is not his that he is slaughtering?
66.32: What are we dealing with here? When he handed it to a guardian and it caused the damage in the house of the guardian and it was sentenced in the house of the guardian and a thief stole it from the house of the guardian.
66.33: And R. Meir holds like R. Yaakov and holds like R. Shimon.
66.34: He holds like R. Yaakov who says:
66.35: If the guardian returned it even after the sentence had been completed, it is regarded as returned.
66.36: And he holds like R. Shimon who says:
66.37: that which causes [the gain or loss of] money is regarded as money.
66.39: Indeed [it speaks of a case] when he slaughtered it himself an
66.4: One who cooks on Shabbat, [if] by mistake, he may eat it; if intentionally he may not eat it, the words of R. Meir.
66.6: [If] by mistake, he may eat it Shabbat is over; if intentionally, he may never eat it.
66.8: [If] by mistake, others may eat it after Shabbat but he may not;
66.9: if intentionally neither he nor others may eat it.

67.0: and R. Meir holds the view that [though generally] one may receive the lashes and pay, one cannot receive the death penalty and pay but these [cases]
67.1: are different, because the Torah has enacted something novel with regard to a fine, and [therefore]  he has to pay, although he has to suffer the death penalty.
